results.name: A Seidel matrix A(n,k) read by antidiagonals downwards.
comment: The first row is a signed version of the Euler numbers A000111.
Other rows are defined by A(n+1,k) = A(n,k) + A(n,k+1).
link: A. Randrianarivony and J. Zeng, Une famille de polynomes qui interpole plusieurs suites classiques de nombres, Adv. Appl. Math. 17 (1996), 1-26. See Section 6 (matrix b_{n,k} on p. 19).
formula: Formulas for the square array A(n,k) (n, k >= 0):
A(n,k) = Sum_{i=0..n} binomial(n, i)*A(0,k+i) for n, k >= 0.
Bivariate e.g.f.: Sum_{n,k >= 0} A(n,k)*(x^n/n!)*(y^k/k!) = (-sech(x + y) + tanh(x + y) + 1)*exp(x).
Formulas for the triangular array T(n,k) = A(k,n-k) (n >= 0, 0 <= k <= n):
T(n,k) = Sum_{i=0..k} binomial(k,i)*T(n-k+i,0) for 0 <= k <= n. (End)
example: Read as triangle T(n,k) = A(k, n-k) (n >= 0, k = 0..n), the first few antidiagonals of the square array A are:
Square array A(n,k) (with rows n >= 0 and columns k >= 0) begins:
program: (PARI) {b(n) = local(v=[1], t); if( n<0, 0, for(k=2, n+2, t=0; v = vector(k, i, if( i>1, t+= v[k+1-i]))); v[2])}; \\ _Michael Somos_'s PARI program for A000111.
A(n, k) = sum(i=0, n, binomial(n, i)*c(k+i)) \\ _Petros Hadjicostas_, Mar 02 2021
